questions.question_text:
Refer to the following.

Router # sh ip route eigrp -
13.0.0.0/8 is variably subnetted, 2 subnets, 2 masks
D 13.0.0.0/8 is a summary, 00:00:32, Null0
What happens to packets that are forwarded from the 13.0.0.0/8 network to the Null0 interface?
questions.answer_description: When an EIGRP router summarizes, it automatically builds a route to null0 for the summarized route. The router to null0 prevents packets that do not match a specific entry in the routing table from following a default route. (The route to null0 causes the packet to be dropped).

questions.answer_ET: Incorrect Answer: OSPF Network LSAs are not originated by Area Border Routers.

choices.B: They are originated by the DR on every multi-access network. They include all attached routers including the DR itself.
choices.C: They are originated by Area Border Routers and are sent into a single area to advertise destinations outside that area.
choices.A: They are originated by every router in the OPSF network. They include all routers on the link, interfaces, the cost of the link, and any known neighbor on the link.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about OSPF Network LSAs?
questions.answer: Incorrect Answer: OSPF Network LSAs are not originated by Area Border Routers.
questions.answer_description:
The point of this question is OSPF Network LSAs
The feature of OSPF Network LSAs is that they are generated by DR, and DR only exist on multi-access network, the use of OSPF Network LSAs is that it list all neighbors around and send it to every router which run OSPF.

discussion.content: B. They are originated by the DR on every multi-access network. They include all attached routers including the DR itself.

questions.answer_ET: E. The "Mismatched" error is caused by the expiration of the OSPF timers.

choices.A: The NProuter has two OSPF neighbors in the "Full" adjacency state.
choices.D: The 10.1.1.1 and 10.1.1.2 routers are not using the default OSPF dead and hello timers setting.
choices.C: The NProuter serial0/0 interface has been configured with an OSPF network type of "pointto-point".
choices.B: The NProuter serial0/0 interface has the OSPF dead timer set to 10 seconds.

questions.answer: E. The "Mismatched" error is caused by the expiration of the OSPF timers.
questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
First we should understand clearly about the line
Dead R 120 C 10, Hello R 30 C 30
The R here means Received and C means Configured. In other words, Dead R is the Dead Timer Received from the neighbor and the Dead C is the Dead Timer of the local router.
Therefore in this case Dead R 120 C 10 means the Death Timer of the neighbor is 120 seconds while the local Dead Timer is 10 seconds, which causes a mismatch. Also we can learn that the local OSPF dead timer is set to 10 seconds.
For your information, by default, OSPF uses a 10-second hello timer and 40-second hold timer on broadcast and point-to-point links, and a 30-second hello timer and 120-second hold timer for all other network types.

discussion.content: B. The NProuter serial0/0 interface has the OSPF dead timer set to 10 seconds.

questions.answer_ET: E. It is not configured correctly to function as specified.

discussion.content: D. It is configured and functioning correctly as an ABR attached to totally stubby area 4.

choices.D: It is configured and functioning correctly as an ABR attached to totally stubby area 4.
choices.C: It is configured and functioning correctly as an ASBR attached to external area 4.
choices.A: It is configured and functioning correctly as an OSPF internal router.
choices.B: It is configured and functioning correctly as an ABR attached to stub area 4.

questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
From the output of the show ip ospf command we notice 2 lines:
+ It is an area border router
+ It is a stub area, no summary LSA in this area (in Area 4)
Therefore we can conclude RouterC is an ABR and it is attached to a totally stubby area (with no summary LSA advertised).
questions.answer: E. It is not configured correctly to function as specified.

questions.answer_ET: data through router C in area 0.
questions.answer: data through router C in area 0.
questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibits. What can be done to fix the problem?

RouterA#debug ip ospf events -

OSPF events debugging is on -
RouterA#
04:43:16: OSPF. Rcv pkt from 10.3.0.2, Ethernet0/1, area 0.0.0.1 mismatch area 0.0.0.2 in the header
04:43:19: OSPF. Rcv hello from 10.100.100.3 area 0 from Ethernet0/0 10.1.0.1
04:43:19: OSPF. End of hello processing
//IMG//

choices.D: Shut down the E0/1 interfaces in router A and router B as OSPF does not allow "back doors" between areas.
choices.B: Change router A interface E0/1 to area 0.0.0.2.
choices.C: Configure the E0/1 interfaces of router A and router B to be in area 0.
choices.A: Change router B E0/1 interface to area 0.
choices.E: Remove the E0/1 interfaces in router A and router B from the OSPF process. Use static routes to route data directly from router A to router B to avoid passing

discussion.content: C. Configure the E0/1 interfaces of router A and router B to be in area 0

questions.answer_description:
Reference:
http://www.cisco.com/en/US/tech/tk365/technologies_white_paper09186a0080094e9e.shtml (See topic: the backbone and area 0)
